column1: White baseplate is a great set of a usually hard to find piece .

column2: The piece can fit to my count 88 minifigures or more if you squeeze them on .

column1: this is a great set that I wish to get many more of in the future so I can have baseplate full of figures from each star wars faction as I am getting into army building with the release of 75280 .

,TRUE,5,5,1,5,4 Zac","2021-04-01T16:44:57.493Z","One piece, two dimensions","

Having once again impatiently and shamelessly failed to wait to open my presents, I received in advance of my birthday both 10270 Bookshop and 11010 White Baseplate. I had hoped to review 10270 but upon finding that this august assemblage has already been reviewed several times, I turn to its two-dimensional but no less fecund kissing cousin for the following appreciation.
Initial impressions. 11010, a baseplate of especial utility for devotees of empty spaces, presents itself inside a stiff sleeve of polypropylene, itself useful for filling up the world&rsquo
column2: s empty spaces with plastic. The front bears a photograph of bricks placed on top of the enclosed baseplate, immediately asserting two motifs: self-referentiality and unrealized potentiality. An age range printed on the sleeve cautions against giving 11010 to children under four, prompting one to wonder under what conditions a plastic plate of ten and one-eighth inches square could pose a choking hazard.

column1: Symphony for the senses. For the eyes, 11010 offers a variety of optical illusions but steadfastly declines to reciprocate one&rsquo
column2: s gaze. The plate draws on a distinguished lineage of abstract expressionism and minimalism but never achieves comparable intensity. It excels in its study of tactile contrasts, however: on one side, a regularly variegated matrix of protruding cylinders
column3: on the other, its smoother inverse.

column1: Of negligible and nonstandard thickness, the plate is relatively supple and produces distinctive sounds when flexed. The plate&rsquo
column2: s sonic qualities are most readily appreciated when loosely grasped from two diagonally opposite corners and shaken vigorously toward and away from one&rsquo
column3: s head. As expected, 11010 produces smooth ululations but its tonal palate remains limited.

column1: The plate initially possessed a pungent nose of processed petroleum. This olfactory dimension quickly faded, but not before evoking childhood memories of digging through boxes of bricks while one'
column2: s parents tried to watch television. Its gustatory attributes are understated, with a slight chemical quality at the forefront masking fainter notes of acidity. The mouthfeel is not unpleasant but quickly becomes monotonous.

column1: Conceptual challenges. 11010 revels, as its number suggests, in binaries: convexity on one face balances concavity on the other, paradoxically evoking presence through absence. The photograph on the front alludes to this dramatic tension, depicting &ldquo
column3: Its relentless self-referentiality disclaims any pretense of meaning, but despite its 1,024 molded self-proclamations that it constitutes &ldquo
column5: nagging doubts persist: Is anything only ever what it appears?

column1: The precise status of 11010 remains unexpectedly challenging, a characteristic common to many Basic offerings but brought into particularly sharp focus by 11010&rsquo
column2: s relentless planar whiteness. It defies received ontologies: What is a brick, precisely? Can one piece be described as a set? The plate poses questions but declines to adjudicate them.

column1: 11010 remains phenomenally limited but not unappealing. Three stars (and apologies to the late Russell Baker).
